clean_story:
"Three bodies. Unpredictable orbits. "

The three-body problem describes how three objects—like stars or planets—move in ways that can’t be predicted exactly.

Imagine trying to juggle three balls while riding a bike.
Even tiny changes—like a gust of wind—can send them flying in wild directions.

In space, gravity pulls all three objects at once, creating chaos.
A small nudge can flip orbits from orderly circles to erratic loops.

Scientists use supercomputers to simulate it, but exact paths stay unknown.

This chaos explains why some star systems eject planets—or collide violently.

Three related subjects are gravity’s hidden rules, black hole dances and space weather storms.
